title: Oil slumps ahead of U.S. inventory data
text:
Oil futures fell Wednesday as investors await official data on U.S. crude inventories after a trade group reported a rise in stocks late Tuesday.

Also weighing on prices were news reports saying Saudi Arabia had restored most crude production, recovering from attacks on its facilities earlier this month.

West Texas Intermediate crude for November delivery CLX19, -2.55% fell $1.06, or 1.9%, to $56.23 a barrel, while November Brent crude BRNX19, -2.54%, the global benchmark, was off $1.27, or 2%, at $60.85 a barrel.

The American Petroleum Institute late Tuesday reported that U.S. crude supplies rose by 1.4 million barrels in the week ended Sept. 20, sources said. They said the trade group also showed a 1.9 million barrel rise in gasoline stocks and a 2.2 million barrel fall in distillate inventories.

The figures come ahead of more closely watched figure from the Energy Information Administration Wednesday morning. Analysts surveyed by S&P Global Platts are looking for a decline in crude inventories of 190,000, while gasoline stocks are seen rising 300,000 barrels and distillate inventories are expected to fall by 600,000 barrels.

Lower run rates by refineries in the Gulf of Mexico due to Tropical Storm Imelda earlier this month are seen putting expectations for a drawdown at risk, said analysts at ING. “The market will be watching closely today to see whether the more widely followed EIA inventory numbers are similar” to the API figures.

Meanwhile, Reuters, citing persons briefed on the operations of Saudi Aramco’s operations, reported that Saudi Arabia restored production capacity to 11.3 million barrels a day, continuing a quick bounceback from the Sept. 14 attacks on facilities that were estimated to have knocked more than 5 million barrels a day out of production.

Reports on the rebound continue to be met with skepticism, however, given the scale of the damage seen to processing facilities. A recent Wall Street Journal report said it could take many months to fully restore operations. Noted Aramco in emergency talks with contractors, offering premium rates for parts and repair work, which could take up to a year.

“Market chatter is clearly trending towards scepticism over the feasible pace of fully restoring Saudi production capacity,” wrote analysts at JBC Energy, a Vienna-based consulting firm.

“Besides expert assessments, these opinions are probably also being fuelled by ongoing talks of unusual crude and product trade involving Saudi Aramco/Aramco Trading,” they wrote. “With all that said, a look at outright prices tells us that at least for now the number of skeptics is either too low or the focus of the market is already back to the rather worrisome economic indications out there.”

In other energy trading, November gasoline RBX19, -2.76% fell 2.3% to $1.5889 a gallon, while November heating oil HOX19, -2.01% was off 1.7% at $1.929 a gallon.

November natural-gas futures NGX19, -1.90% declined 0.9% to $2.503 per million British thermalunits.
description: Oil futures fall as investors await official data on U.S. crude inventories after a trade group reported a rise in stocks, while reports indicate Saudi...
